qas.question: What organization is Craig Venter and Francis Collins associated with?
What year was the announcement that the human genome had been mapped made in?
What doesn't the genetic variation within the human species support?
What is a social concept, not a scientific one?
What happens when scientists try to apply science to sort out social differences?

context: Craig Venter and Francis Collins of <a0_0>the National Institute of Health<a0_0/> jointly made the announcement of the mapping of the human genome in <a1_0>2000<a1_0/>. Upon examining the data from the genome mapping, Venter realized that although the genetic variation within the human species is on the order of 1–3% (instead of the previously assumed 1%), the types of variations do not support <a2_0>notion of genetically defined races<a2_0/>. Venter said, "<a3_0>Race<a3_0/> is a social concept. It's not a scientific one. There are no bright lines (that would stand out), if we could compare all the sequenced genomes of everyone on the planet." "When we try to apply science to try to sort out these social differences, <a4_0>it all falls apart<a4_0/>."
